questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with epiphora, and probing reveals a soft block at 7 mm. What is the best treatment option for this condition?
Which bones are cut/removed during external Dacryocystorhinostomy?
A 3-month-old child was brought to the outpatient department (OPD) with symptoms of photophobia and watering of the eyes. Which of the following is not a cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D

questions.text: What is the accurate order of staining in patients with dry eyes? i. Fluorescein stain ii. Lissamine green iii. Rose Bengal stain
questions.explanation:
Investigations of dry eye

1, Slit-lamp examination
  • Superficial corneal erosions
  • Inadequate tear lake volume
  • Early tear film break-up time
  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Conjunctival surface irregularities
  • Meibomian gland dysfunction

2. Schirmer’s Test:
  • Schirmer’s test is used to diagnose aqueous deficiency dry eye disease.

Schirmer's Test 1

  • Measures both basal and reflex tear secretions
  • Uses Whatman-4 filter paper, kept in the lower fornix at the junction of lateral one-third and medial two-thirds.
  • After 5 minutes, wetting of the filter strip from the bent end is measured.
  • Normal value: >15 mm
  • 5-10 mm: Mild to moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS).
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

[1]

Schirmer's Test 2

  • Measures only basal secretion under anesthesia

3. Phenol Red Test
  • A modified Schirmer’s test using a cotton thread impregnated with phenol red dye.
  • The thread is placed in the lower fornix for 15 seconds.
  • Phenol dye changes from yellow to red depending on the pH of the tears.
  • Wet length: >20 mm: Normal.
  • <10 mm: Severe dry eye.
  • ≤19 mm as borderline dry eye.

4. Tear Film Break-Up Time (TBUT)
  • Tear film stained with sodium fluorescein 1% is observed under a slit lamp, and time is noted after the patient blinks.
  • The interval between the complete blink and the first appearance of a ‘dark’ dry spot on the cornea is recorded as TBUT.
  • It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears.
  • Normal: 15-35 seconds
  • < 10 seconds indicates unstable tear film.

5. Rose Bengal or Lissamine Green

Stain devitalized, desiccated corneal and conjunctival epithelium red or green.

 

6. Alcian Blue

Stains particulate matter in the tear film due to mucus

7. Tear Osmolarity

Increased in dry eye

8. Tear to Lysozyme ratio

Between 0.9 and 0.6 indicates dry eye.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chronic dacryocystitis. She complains of recurrent tearing, discharge, and mild swelling in the inner corner of the eye. The clinical findings and history are consistent with chronic dacryocystitis. What should be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Dacryocystorhinostomy

Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

Clinical Features/ Sequelae
  1. Stage of cellulitis: Painful swelling at the lacrimal sac, epiphora, fever, redness, and oedema.
  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  4. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Image

 

Complications

Conjunctivitis, corneal ulcer, lid abscess, orbital cellulitis, facial cellulitis, rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

Treatment
  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later.
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.
  • Conservative: Probing and syringing (early stages).
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage.
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a 55-year-old woman who is experiencing long-term mucopurulent discharge from her left eye and swelling near the inner corner of the eye?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

Clinical Features/ Sequelae
  1. Stage of cellulitis: Painful swelling at the lacrimal sac, epiphora, fever, redness, and oedema.
  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  1. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Image

Complications

Conjunctivitis, corneal ulcer, lid abscess, orbital cellulitis, facial cellulitis, rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

Treatment
  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later. (Option C)
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.
  • Conservative: Probing and syringing (early stages).
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage. (Option A)
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age (>60y). (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries use this instrument?

Which of the following treatments is appropriate for a 3-month-old child with a mucopurulent discharge from the right puncta and a history of increased watering in the right eye, as noticed by the mother?
questions.correct_answer: C. Sac massage with topical antibiotics
questions.explanation:
< 6-9 months

Lacrimal sac massage with topical antibiotics (Option C)

9 months - 4 years

Bowman’s probing with syringing (Option A) (Option B)

> 4 years

Dacryocystorhinostomy (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  1. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later.
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.

  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage.
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age.

questions.text: In Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the point of opening of the lacrimal sac is into which nasal meatus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Middle meatu
